_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FreshPoint Lancaster Foods LLC (FP Lancaster) in Jessup, Maryland, is committed to employee,
public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by FP Lancasters
comprehensive accidental release prevention program. It is the facilitys policy to implement
appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. If such releases do
occur, there are highly trained employees on hand to control and mitigate the effects of the
releases.

There is one (1) regulated substance present at this facility. This substance is ammonia
(anhydrous). The highest expected inventory of ammonia (anhydrous) at this facility is 26,000
pounds (rounded to two significant digits for reporting purposes).

The facility has taken the following steps as required by 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part(§) 68 of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulations. The ammonia (anhydrous)
process is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process
Safety Management (PSM) Standard under 29 CFR §1910.119. In addition, the facility is also
subject to the EPAs Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act (EPCRA) Section 302 reporting requirements. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release
prevention program that are in place.

Process Safety Information:
Information related to the hazards of the ammonia refrigeration system installed at the
facility has been compiled. Prior to conducting the initial and subsequent hazard analyses,
the process safety information was reviewed and utilized in identifying and mitigating
recognized hazards. The process safety information was also used in the development of
the operating procedures.

Process Hazard Analysis:
Comprehensive studies were conducted to ensure that hazards associated with the
ammonia refrigeration process were identified and controlled efficiently. The methodology
used to carry out these analyses was the what-if/checklist approach. The studie

s were
undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process
operations and will be revalidated at a regular interval of every five (5) years. Any findings
related to the process hazard analyses are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures:
Operating procedures are maintained at the facility. These procedures address the various
modes of operation of the ammonia refrigeration system such as initial start-up, normal
operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal
shutdown, and start-up after a turnaround. The information is readily accessible to
operators involved in the process.

Training:
A training program is in place to ensure that employees operating processes are competent
in the operating procedures associated with those processes. New employees receive basic
classroom training in process operations, followed by on-the job supervision until they are
deemed competent to work independently. Refresher training on operating procedures is
provided as required.

Mechanical Integrity:
Documented maintenance checks are conducted on process equipment to ensure proper
operation. Process equipment examined during these checks includes pressure vessels,
storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, and pumps. Maintenance
operations are carried out by qualified personnel. Any equipment deficiencies identified
by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change:
Written procedures are in place to manage changes in process chemicals, technology,
equipment, and processes. Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other
employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process operations are
promptly made aware of and given training to deal with the modifications.

Pre-Startup Reviews:
Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modification of established
processes are conducted as a regular practice. These re

views are conducted to confirm that
construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe
start-up prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits:
Compliance audits are conducted on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions
set out under the Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation are being implemented.
These audits are carried out at least once every three (3) years and any corrective actions
required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

Incident Investigation:
Incidents that have resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a
regulated substance are promptly investigated. These investigations are undertaken to
identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the
release from recurring. All incident reports are retained for a minimum of five (5) years.

Employee Participation:
The facility strongly believes that process management and accident prevention are a team
effort. Company employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident
prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, the employees have
access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP
regulation, including information resulting from process hazard analyses.

Contractors:
Contractors are utilized to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.
Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance
is completed. The Facility has a strict policy of informing contractors of known potential
hazards related to the contractor's work and the process. Contractors are also informed of
all the procedures for emergency notification and evacuation, should an accidental release
of a regulated substance occur.

The Facility has not had any reportable accidents or incidents during the past five (5) years.  This Facility has coordinated with the

Local Emergency Planning Committee and nearby responders. This facility has its own Emergency Planning and Response Plan (EPRP) as well. The EPRP includes actions to be taken in response to accidental releases of regulated substances as
well as procedures for informing the public and local response agencies of a chemical release.

Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of the accidental release prevention program. Regular reviews of the ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system and procedures will continue. Additionally, there will be continued notifications and pre-planning with the Local Fire Department.
